channel.title: Why are so many gaming companies destroying their old game-series
channel.description:
Let's take Leisure Suit Larry for example:
Many people loved that adventure series, because of the puzzles and for its jokes. There were plans for a Larry 8 in 1998, but sadly it was canceled in the end (among many other well-known and successful adventure games like Space Quest 7).
I don't really now, why every gaming company thought, that the times for adventure games would be over. It really makes no sense to me, because it was a genre with huge success, even through the nineties were the beginning of the first 3D shooters.
But after some years, Sierra intended to revive their successful adventure games and released a new Larry game, named "Magna Cum Laude". But it wasn't Larry anymore, no adventure, but a collection of boring mini-games. As a result, they got bad reviews, bad sales and every true fan hated them from that on. So, what was the point? And the worse, they didn't seem to learn from that lesson and released another "piece of shit"-sequel: Leisure Suit Larry: Box Office Bust.
But Larry is just one example...there are many other game series, that got destroyed the same way.
Here is a list of common mistakes for a sequel:
1. Changing the genre or the tasks of a game (classic adventure -> mini-games)
2. Writing a new plot, that doesn't pick up any events from the predecessor (even, if there was a cliffhanger)
3. Scrapping well-known characters, that appeared in every previous game of the series before (In the new Larry games, it is even the hero itself, who got replaced)
4. Hiring new voice-actors for well-known characters, who doesn't even have a similar voice.
5. Changing controls, even if it's not wanted, nor necessary (Point-n-Click is the only true movement for adventures games and there was no need to change that)
6. Changing the graphics model, even if it's not wanted, nor necessary (not every game needs real-time 3D graphics, while nice 2D pre-rendered backdrops are fitting perfectly for those kind of video games)
7. Eliminating elements, everybody loved in the previous games or replacing them with shit (subtle jokes for example)
I think there are much more things, they can do wrong. The only question is why...why are they doing this?

item.title: Why are so many gaming companies destroying their old game-series
item.dc:creator: bulbman
item.description:
Grey Acumen:

You people do realize that like how all squares are rectangles, but not all rectangles are squares, “zombie” does not automatically equate to “undead” and as such you can have Living Zombies. Zombie is the state of acting without conscious control of your actions, which can refer to the animation of a corpse like a puppet; whether by stimulating the nervous system directly at the brain stem, through a robotic skeletal structure manipulating the limbs of the corpse, or through “magic”, or can also refer to the external control of a living person’s mind, whether through hypnotism, parasites, or “magic”

Yes, RE4 and RE5 plagas can be considered zombies, like I said. However, if you didn’t know they were being controlled, they could also appear to be bat shit crazy cultists. When a guy with a pitchfork tries to kill you, you would probably think “Holy shit! This guys fucking insane!”, when you see a smelly man with flesh hanging off eating a corpse you might think “Holy shit! A fucking zombie.” So, the plagas of the new RE games are rectangles that look like triangles. Wait, what?:retard:

Grey Acumen:

As for the main topic itself, while there are some good points being made, it feels like I’m listening to all the old requests made of black mesa “you should make it exactly like HL1, so don’t change anything, just make it BETTER”
Damned if they don’t change anything, damned if they do, so I’ll ride along with the damned if they do option, at least then we get something different and they can always go BACK to their roots if they get enough CONSTRUCTIVE feedback (not just “this new style sucks, I like the old style better”)

While I do agree with this for the most part, would you feel the same way if Black Mesa was released and the devs made it a Halo clone because that was THIER definition of “better”. Of course Black Mesa is a bad example because it is a remake of a game that is already out, so, the “you should make it exactly like HL1, so don’t change anything, just make it BETTER” statement is pretty close to what they should be doing, they have to change some things, but the gameplay should stay the same.

item.title: Why are so many gaming companies destroying their old game-series
item.dc:creator: bulbman
item.description:
Morrussian:

I liked the change
It’s like the shift in the Metal Gear gameplay. Unusual, but progressive.
Sure, the old system was excellent, but the new system allows for a better paced story line, and a lesser guarantee of sequence breaking. (Which… it’s very easy to beat the first one in 1.5 hours, good for a quick distraction)
I like the old system, but the linearity was difficult to grasp without a guide, and if you didn’t have help, you would be out of ammo fast. The new system coddles you more, but I don’t think it’s problematic at all. Yeah though… they do use a genre change to aid it, survival/horror-action/survival, still a fun game

…and If you’ve never played Resident “Wiivel” 4, you’re missing out

The new ones are good games, no doubt. But they are not even the same type of game. Also, I found myself running out of ammo in the 5th one much more, for an action game ammo drops can be rare, and only 5 rounds, wtf, that’s like one kill. Not to mention Sheva burning through all my ammo, most of it into the back of my head. The game would have been much better without her. Think back to RE4, what were the worst parts of the game? Ashley, to put it simply. Sheva is like a permanent Ashley clone with a gun.

I might make a new thread for Resident Evil discussion, that would fall under technology and gaming right?

Why doesn’t some mind-controlling parasite not really count as zombies? I mean, it seems that in the end it results in roughly the same behavior.

It’s not that they’re not “zombies”, zombies are not real, so there really isn’t a fixed definition of a zombie. No, the behavior is quite diferent, the original zombies wanted to eat you and anything else alive to try, fruitlessly, to satisfy thier immense hunger. The plagas zombies are being controlled by a “mastermind” to do thier bidding and thus turns the plot into “Kill the baddy in charge” , which is cliche and, imo, stupid, rather than actual survival horror where your main objective is to escape alive.

item.title: Why are so many gaming companies destroying their old game-series
item.dc:creator: Fnoigy
item.description:
Someonerandm:

Bottom line: Almost any problem in gaming can be summarized in one word: Consumers.

Not greedy executives, not lazy devs, not annoying anti-piracy measures. Consumers.

They are the idiots who buy the worthless games, or don’t buy the actually good game. The average consumer is a total idiot with an IQ of about 3. Thats why much of gaming is going to hell.

That and casuals. Lots of casuals.

And by casuals I mean motion controls.

No, greedy executives and their investors are also to blame. Casuals, n00b-PwN1n’ H@x0rZ, sports nuts, Deus Ex fans, and everybody else could exist and be happy separately, but the executives want MAXIMUM PROFITS HUMANLY POSSIBLE, so they want to make games that will appeal to as many different people as they can. They have mostly snuffed out any sort of niches in gaming, so games are more becoming the jack of all trades (Jack, who happens to also be the village idiot), but it isn’t very good at any of them.

They’re making sure games appeal JUST enough to anybody that they’ll be likely to buy it thinking it’s for them, when either the game is really designed for nobody, or for the dumbest, lowest common denominator.
